commander.name: Generale di Corpo d'Armata Enrico Pitassi Mannella
commander.previous_service: Career officer, commanded XXII Corps from reformation in Libya through capture at Tobruk
commander.fate: Taken prisoner 23 January 1941 at fall of Tobruk

aircraft.note: No organic aircraft. Air support provided by Regia Aeronautica from theater assets.

fuel_reserves.notes: Severely depleted by January 1941 siege conditions. Limited resupply during British encirclement.

ammunition_days.notes: Critically low ammunition stocks by mid-January 1941. Artillery rationing in effect from 15 January.

water_reserves.notes: Water supply challenged by damage to Tobruk desalination facilities from British naval bombardment

medical_supplies.notes: Adequate medical supplies but overwhelmed by casualties from British bombardment and assault

maintenance_capability.notes: Limited workshop facilities in Tobruk. Many vehicles immobilized by lack of spare parts and fuel.

supply_lines.notes: Corps completely encircled by 7 January 1941. No overland resupply possible. Minimal sea resupply attempted under British naval interdiction.

temperature_range.notes: Mild winter temperatures in coastal Cyrenaica

terrain.challenges: Static defense in prepared positions. Limited mobility due to fuel shortages and British encirclement.

weather_conditions.impact_on_operations: Clear weather favored British air superiority and naval bombardment. Limited dust for concealment.

historical_notes.formation: XXII Corps reformed in Tobruk, Libya on 15 September 1939. Participated in Italian invasion of Egypt as part of 10th Army in September 1940.
historical_notes.disbandment: Corps disbanded 23 January 1941 after fall of Tobruk to British and Australian forces
historical_notes.battle_context: After defeat at Sidi Barrani (9-11 December 1940), XXII Corps withdrew to Tobruk and established defensive positions. Corps was encircled by 7 January 1941 during British Operation Compass. British assault began 21 January; last resistance surrendered afternoon of 22 January. Commander Pitassi Mannella and entire staff captured.
historical_notes.casualties: Approximately 25,000 prisoners taken by British/Australian forces. Corps effectively ceased to exist.
historical_notes.strategic_significance: Fall of Tobruk completed destruction of Italian 10th Army in Cyrenaica. Opened way for British advance to El Agheila before German intervention (Afrika Korps arrival February 1941).
